block.p: ATTRACTIONS
Museums and Sites

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 34-12 36th Street, at 35th Avenue, Astoria, Queens. ''The Sopranos,'' screenings from the show's first two seasons; through June 25. Tomorrow at 2 p.m., episodes 17 and 18; at 4:15 p.m., episodes 19 and 20. Sunday at 2 p.m., episodes 21 and 22; at 4:15 p.m., episodes 23 and 24. Evening screenings, $8; $4 for members and the elderly. Museum hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, noon to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. All activities are free with museum admission unless otherwise indicated. Admission: $8.50; the elderly and students, $5.50; ages 5 to 18, $4.50; 4 and under, free. Information: (718) 784-0077.
ATTRACTIONS
Museums and Sites

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 34-12 36th Street, at 35th Avenue, Astoria, Queens. ''The Sopranos,'' screenings from the show's first two seasons; through June 25. Tomorrow at 2 p.m., episodes 17 and 18; at 4:15 p.m., episodes 19 and 20. Sunday at 2 p.m., episodes 21 and 22; at 4:15 p.m., episodes 23 and 24. Evening screenings, $8; $4 for members and the elderly. Museum hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, noon to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. All activities are free with museum admission unless otherwise indicated. Admission: $8.50; the elderly and students, $5.50; ages 5 to 18, $4.50; 4 and under, free. Information: (718) 784-0077.

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. Opening today, ''Fighting Dinosaurs: New Discoveries From Mongolia,'' featuring one of the most famous fossil finds in the world; through Oct. 29. ''Mongolia Observed: Photographs Present and Past,'' featuring 40 color images by Robert Peck and black-and-white photographs by the explorer Ray Chapman Andrews from the 1920's and 30's. Tonight at 7 in the Kaufmann Theater, the author Bara Caseley Swain presents vignettes celebrating women. Imax films are ''Epic Journeys: The Great Migrations'' and ''Dolphins.'' In the Imax Theater tonight and tomorrow night at 9, ''Laser Aerosmith in 3-D''; at 10, ''Led Zeppelin.'' Laser show tickets: $12. Museum hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 8:45 p.m. Admission (suggested donation): $10 for adults; $7.50 for students and the elderly; $6 for children. Combination tickets are available. Information: (212) 769-5100; advance tickets: (212) 769-5200.

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY'S ROSE CENTER FOR EARTH AND SPACE, Central Park West at 81st Street. This 333,500-square-foot, seven-floor, 120-foot-high exhibition and research center includes the new Hayden Planetarium, the Cullman Hall of the Universe and the Gottesman Hall of Planet Earth. The Hayden Planetarium contains the Space Theater, presenting ''Passport to the Universe,'' and the Big Bang Theater, featuring narrated visual and audio effects simulating the beginning of the universe. ''Starry Nights: Fridays Under the Sphere,'' 6 to 8 p.m., music with Jerry Gonzalez and the Fort Apache Band. Free with admission; food and cash bar. Hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays to 8:45 p.m. Space shows run throughout the day. Admission (suggested donation) to the American Museum of Natural History, which includes the Rose Center: $10; for students and the elderly, $7.50; children 12 and under, $6; under 2, free. Admission to the museum, the Rose Center and the Hayden Planetarium space show: $19; students and the elderly, $14; children 12 and under, $11.50; under 2, free. Information: (212) 769-5100. Reservations: (212) 769-5200.

LOWER EAST SIDE TENEMENT MUSEUM, 90 Orchard Street, at Broome Street. A look at the urban immigrant experience. The museum includes a partly restored tenement at 97 Orchard Street. ''Firecrackers: Chinatown Today,'' photographic works by Andrew Garn mounted on light boxes; through Tuesday. Guided tours: Tuesdays through Fridays at 1, 2, 3 and 4 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, every half-hour beginning at 11 a.m. until the last tour at 4:30 p.m. Suggested donation: $3. Museum hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, noon to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Free. Tour prices: $9; students, the elderly and children over 5, $7; children 5 and under, free. Special prices for two and three tours. Information: (212) 431-0233.

MUSEUM OF CHINESE IN THE AMERICAS, 70 Mulberry Street, Chinatown. On permanent display is ''Where Is Home? Chinese in the Americas,'' a collection of photographs and other artifacts, and ''Family Portraits,'' photographs of Chinatown residents. ''Returning Home,'' an installation by Brenda Joy Lem using family photographs and oral interviews to document her family history; through June 30. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, noon to 5 p.m.; closed holidays. Admission: $3; the elderly and students, $1; 12 and under and museum members, free. Information: (212) 619-4785.

MUSEUM OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, Fifth Avenue at 103rd Street. ''New York Now 2000: Contemporary Work in Photography,'' through Oct. 15. Tomorrow at 2 p.m., the museum curator Bob Shamis will give a gallery talk on the exhibition. ''A Tribute to Patricia Zipprodt,'' the costume designer, through July 2; tomorrow at 2 p.m., a discussion on her career and influence. ''New York: Songs of the City,'' through Sept. 10. Hours: Tuesdays 10 a.m. to 2 p.m., for registered groups only; Wednesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Suggested admission: $7; the elderly, students and children, $4; families, $12. Information: (212) 534-1672.

MUSEUM OF JEWISH HERITAGE: A LIVING MEMORIAL TO THE HOLOCAUST, 18 First Place, at West Street and Battery Place, Battery Park City. Artifacts, documents, photographs, videos and film clips are included in exhibitions on the Holocaust and on Jewish life before and after World War II. Sunday at noon, 2 and 3 p.m., a Father's Day tour, introducing visitors to the themes of the museum through artifacts that focus on the role of fatherhood in Jewish history and ritual. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays, until 8 p.m.; Fridays and the eves of Jewish holidays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; closed Saturdays. Admission: $7; students and the elderly, $5; age 5 and under, free. Tickets can be bought in advance through Ticketmaster, (212) 307-4007, or by calling the museum on the day of the visit, (212) 945-0039. Information: (212) 509-6130.

NATIONAL MUSEUM OF THE AMERICAN INDIAN, Alexander Hamilton United States Customs House, 1 Bowling Green, Lower Manhattan. ''Reservation X: The Power of Place,'' multimedia installations by seven artists, through Aug. 20. Tomorrow and Sunday from 11 a.m. to 3 p.m., C. Maxx Steven, a featured artist in the exhibition ''Reservation X,'' will talk about her installation piece and how her art is formed by her Seminole heritage. Hours: daily, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays until 8 p.m. Free. Information: (212) 514-3888.

NEW-YORK HISTORICAL SOCIETY, 170 Central Park West, near 77th Street. ''Stork Club,'' including an environmental installation that mimics the floor plan of the club, photographs and memorabilia belonging to the family of Sherman Billingsley, the owner of the club; on view through Oct. 1. ''Magnum, Our Turning World: Photographs, 1989-1999,'' through tomorrow. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; students and the elderly, $3; 12 and under, free. Information: (212) 873-3400.
Gardens

BROOKLYN BOTANIC GARDEN, 900 Washington Avenue, Prospect Heights. More than 12,000 kinds of plants from around the world are displayed on 52 acres. The roses are in peak bloom through June. The Japanese Hill and Pond Garden has recently reopened; guided tours (hourly from 1 to 4 p.m.), programs and events through Sunday. Gallery hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Admission: $3; $1.50 for students and the elderly; free for children 15 and under; free on Tuesdays, except holidays; and free from 10 a.m. to noon on Saturdays. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 8 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. The conservatory closes 30 minutes before the grounds. Information: (718) 623-7200.

NEW YORK BOTANICAL GARDEN, 200th Street and Kazimiroff Boulevard, Fordham, the Bronx. The grounds include 27 specialty gardens and plant collections. Alpine plants from six continents are at their peak through mid-June in the Rock Garden. Garden hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Everett Children's Adventure Garden hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 1 p.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Grounds admission free for all on Wednesdays and from 10 a.m. to noon on Saturdays. There are also combination packages. Parking: $5. Information: (718) 817-8700.
Zoos

BRONX ZOO, Bronx River Parkway and Fordham Road, Fordham. Some 265 wooded acres are devoted to naturalistic habitats, including Jungle World, African Plains, the Baboon Reserve, the World of Birds, the Aitken Sea Bird Colony (with daily penguin feedings at 3:30 p.m., weather permitting), Big Birds and the Congo Gorilla Forest. The Butterfly Zone has reopened through Oct. 1, with thousands of butterflies and moths and an area where visitors can see the metamorphosis of chrysalides, or cocoons, into butterflies or moths. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Admission, $9; $5 for children 2 to 12 and the elderly; free for everyone on Wednesdays. Parking: $6. Information: (718) 367-1010.

PROSPECT PARK ZOO, 450 Flatbush Avenue, near Empire Boulevard, Prospect Heights, Brooklyn. Geared to children, with sea lions, wallabies, baboons, farm animals and a discovery trail. Sea lion feedings daily at 11:30 a.m., 2 and 4 p.m. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; weekends, 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Admission: $2.50; the elderly, $1.25; children 3 to 12, 50 cents; 2 and under, free. Information: (718) 399-7339.
Cruises

CIRCLE LINE CRUISES, leaving from Pier 83, 42nd Street at the Hudson River, Clinton. A two-hour 24-mile cruise around southern Manhattan, passing landmarks like Ellis Island and the United Nations, daily at 11 a.m. and 3:30 p.m. Tickets: $18; children 12 and under, $10; the elderly, $16. A three-hour 35-mile cruise around all of Manhattan, today at 10 a.m., noon, 1:30 and 2:30 p.m.; beginning tomorrow, daily at 9:30 and 10:30 a.m., 12:30, 1:30, 2:30 and 4:30 p.m. Tickets: $22; children 12 and under, $12; the elderly, $19. ''Harbor Lights,'' Fridays through Sundays, 7 p.m. Tickets: $18; children 12 and under, $10; the elderly, $16. Information: (212) 563-3200.

WORLD YACHT, leaving from Pier 81, 41st Street at the Hudson River, Clinton. Daily dinner cruises along the West Side of Manhattan and around New York Harbor, from 7 to 10 p.m., boarding at 6 p.m. Prices: Fridays, $75; Saturdays, $79; Sundays, $67 (does not include beverages, taxes or gratuities). Brunch cruises sail on Sundays from 12:30 to 2:30 p.m., with boarding at 11:30 a.m. Price: $39.95. Information: (212) 630-8100.

N.Y. WATERWAY, leaving from Pier 78, West 38th Street and 12th Avenue, Manhattan. Daily two-hour full Manhattan cruise, at 10:30 a.m. and 1:30 p.m., through Nov. 12. Tickets: $24; $19 for the elderly; $12 for children ages 3 to 12; 2 and younger, free. Daily, a 90-minute cruise of New York Harbor; at 10 a.m., noon, 2 and 4 p.m. Tickets: $19; the elderly, $16; ages 3 to 12, $9; 2 and younger, free. Fridays at 10:15 p.m., Disco cruise. Price: $19; $9 for children. A 70-minute twilight tour leaves daily, except Tuesday, at 8:45 p.m.; additional tours on Saturdays at 7:15 and 10:15 p.m. and on Sundays at 7:15. Tickets: $19; the elderly, $16; children, $9. Information: (800) 533-3779.
ON THE STREET

SECOND AVENUE STUYVESANT PARK FAIR, Second Avenue from 14th to 23rd Street, Manhattan. Art, antiques, jewelry, crafts and food. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by Stuyvesant Park Neighborhood Association.
ST. JOSEPH'S SCHOOL FESTIVAL, Washington Place from Grove to Macdougal Street, Greenwich Village. Crafts, food. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m.
CHELSEA SUMMER FESTIVAL, Eighth Avenue from 14th to 23rd Street. More than 300 vendors, entertainment. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. Sponsored by Chelsea Midtown Democrats.
WOMEN'S DEMOCRATIC STREET FAIR, Astor Place, between Broadway and Lafayette Streets. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.
INTERNATIONAL CULTURES FESTIVAL, Madison Avenue from 42nd to 57th Streets, Midtown Manhattan. Antiques, food and crafts. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by International Cultures Foundation Inc.

23RD PLANTATHON AND MUSIC FESTIVAL, Broadway from 73rd to 86th Street. Plants, flowers, antiques, collectibles and food. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the West Side Federation of Neighborhood and Block Associations.
RECREATION

WABC FATHER'S DAY FIGHT AGAINST PROSTATE CANCER, Central Park. Five-kilometer race; fun run for youngsters. Sunday at 8:30 a.m. Sponsored by the New York Road Runners Club. Advance registration fee, $17; $12 for club members; $10 for junior and senior members. Same-day registration: $22; $15 for members; $12 for junior and senior club members. Information: (212) 860-4455.
EVENTS

BLOOMSDAY ON BROADWAY XIX, Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street. Actors are to read from James Joyce's ''Ulysses'' and his poetry, as well as works by Yeats, John Millington Synge, Seamus Heaney and others. Frank McCourt, Malachy McCourt, Keir Dullea, Mia Dillon and Fritz Weaver are to read. Tonight, 7 to midnight. Tickets: $15; $11 for students and the elderly; $10 for members, (212) 864-5400.
BOOK SALE, St. Agnes Branch, New York Public Library, 444 Amsterdam Avenue, at 81st Street, Manhattan. Today, noon to 5 p.m. and tomorrow 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. Information: (212) 877-4380.

PAUL WINTER'S SEVENTH SUMMER SOLSTICE CELEBRATION, Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street, Morningside Heights. The saxophonist Paul Winter and his world music ensemble perform three concerts to mark the change of seasons. Also appearing will be Karan Casey, a singer; Jerry O'Sullivan, an Uilleann-piper; Arto Tuncboyaciyan, a singer and percussionist, and Vardan Grigoryan, a woodwind player. Tonight at 7:30; tomorrow at 4:30 a.m. and 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $28 (general admission) and $45 (reserved seating) for the evening concerts; $15 for the sunrise concert. Information: (212) 662-2133.

24TH AMERICAN CRAFTS FESTIVAL AT LINCOLN CENTER, Damrosch Park and the Josie L. Robertson Plaza, Columbus Avenue and 64th Street. More than 400 crafts displays, as well as entertainment. Tomorrow, noon to 9 p.m.; Sunday, 11 a.m. to 9 p.m.

RIVERMUSIC FESTIVAL, Chelsea Piers, Pier 62, Hudson River and 23rd Street. A monthly music festival that runs through September, each offering a different form of music. Salsa is the focus of tomorrow's concert at 6 p.m. Tickets, $10; free for children under 16. There will also be free concerts tomorrow and Sunday at noon. Information: (212) 336-6881.

BLOOMS AND BRASS FOR DAD, Conservatory Garden, Central Park. A free tour of the garden, followed by a performance by a brass quintet from the Mannes College of Music. Meets Sunday at 2 p.m. at the Vanderbilt Gate, Fifth Avenue and 105th Street. Sponsored by the Central Park Conservancy. Information: (212) 860-1370.

FATHER'S DAY AT THE INTREPID, Intrepid Sea-Air-Space Museum, Pier 86, 46th Street and 12th Avenue, Manhattan. ''Flight Deck Olympics,'' featuring a relay race and a signal flag hoist. Sunday, noon to 3 p.m. Admission, $12; $9 for students, reservists and veterans and the elderly; $6 for children 2 to 11; $2 for children 2 to 5; free for children under 2, active military personnel and museum members. Information: (212) 957-7055.
WALKING TOURS

FATHER'S DAY WEEKEND IN CENTRAL PARK, Manhattan. Learn about the early history of the park with stops at Strawberry Fields, Literary Walk, the Arsenal and Bethesda Fountain. Meets tomorrow at 2 p.m. and Sunday at noon. Sponsored by N.Y.C. Discovery Tours. Fee: $12. Information and meeting place: (212) 465-3331.

''BROOKLYN BRIDGE, BROOKLYN HEIGHTS, BROOKLYN DODGERS.'' A walk across the Brooklyn Bridge and a stroll through Brooklyn Heights, with stops at sites associated with baseball history, including the spot where Jackie Robinson was signed and the 1860 clubhouse of the Brooklyn Excelsiors. Meets tomorrow at 5 p.m. and Sunday at 2:30 p.m. Sponsored by N.Y.C. Discovery Tours. Fee: $12. Information and meeting place: (212) 465-3331.

''HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEST VILLAGE: AN OVERVIEW TOUR IN TWO PARTS.'' Stops at locations dating from the 18th and 19th centuries to the present, including sites of importance in the lives of Thomas Paine and Jimi Hendrix. Tomorrow and Sunday at 11:45 a.m. and 2:15 p.m. Fee: $11 for the first part, $5 for the second part. Sponsored by Gotham Walk. Information and meeting place: (212) 629-1886.

''JOE SENT ME: A HISTORIC SPEAKEASY TOUR'' explores three former speaks in SoHo and Greenwich Village. Meets tomorrow at 6 p.m., at the southeast corner of Prince Street and Broadway, SoHo. Fee: $10, cost of beverages extra. Sponsored by Street Smarts N.Y. Information: (212) 969-8262.

''ANNUAL FATHER'S DAY MULTIETHNIC EATING TOUR,'' a walking and eating tour of the Jewish Lower East Side, Chinatown and Little Italy. Meets on Sunday at 1 p.m. at the southeast corner of Delancey and Essex Streets. Sponsored by Big Onion Walking Tours. Fee: $15; $13 for students and the elderly. Reservations: (212) 439-1090.

GRAVESEND, Brooklyn. Eric J. Ierardi, a historian and author, leads a tour of the neighborhood. Meets Sunday at 9 a.m. in front of the Gravesend Cemetery, Gravesend Neck Road near McDonald Avenue. Sponsored by the Gravesend Historical Society. Suggested donation: $5. Reservations: (718) 627-5617

''WORLD OF OUR FATHERS: THE OLD JEWISH LOWER EAST SIDE.'' Includes the history, food and landmarks of this ethnic neighborhood. Meets Sunday at 1 P.M. at Straus Square, East Broadway, Essex and Canal Streets. Sponsored by Joyce Gold History Tours of New York. Fee: $12. Information: (212) 242-5762.

''THE ART OF FILMMAKING: NEW YORK'S UPPER WEST SIDE,'' Manhattan. Rebecca Winson, a documentary filmmaker, leads a fantasy search for film locations and discusses the difficulties of filming in New York City. Sunday at 11 a.m. Sponsored by the 92d Street Y. Fee, $18. Reservations and meeting place: (212) 996-1100.
